case_vignette:
A 1-year-old, pale-looking boy presents with high-grade fever and ecchymosis, which he has been experiencing for the past 2 weeks. The boy has achieved all developmental milestones on time and has no history of medical illness in the past. Lab investigations reveal the following:
Hemoglobin 5.5 g/dL
WBC 112,000/mm3
Platelets 15,000/mm3
ESR 105/1st hour
The boy is referred to a hematologist, who suspects that he may be suffering from the neoplastic proliferation of immature B cells. The physician decides to do a flow cytometry analysis.
question: Detection of which  markers would help confirm the suspected diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been feeling really high fever and I've noticed some unusual large purple spots on my skin that just showed up recently.
How old are you?
I am 1 year old.
Does the patient have a history of any medical conditions or take any medications?
No, I've never had any medical issues in the past and I don't take any medications.
Is there a family history of bleeding disorders or similar symptoms?
I can't tell you about my family history, as I'm just a 1-year-old and don't have that information.
I understand. Have you noticed any unusual bleeding or bruising in your child?
Yes, there have been some large purple spots appearing on my skin.
**Final Diagnosis:** Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) with Petechiae

trial_0.vignette_frq: CD10, CD19, CD20, CD22, and HLA-DR
